biogHist.abstract: A member of the Liberal Party of Australia, Bernice Pfitzner filled a casual vacancy in the Legislative Council of the Parliament of South Australia in 1990. An emigrant from Singapore and a medical practitioner by profession she was the second person of Chinese descent to be elected to the South Australian parliament. She was defeated at the 1997 election.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: 'Pfitzner, Bernice', in The Australian Women's Register, National Foundation for Australian Women and The University of Melbourne

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Interview with Dr the Hon Bernice Pfitzner, medical practitioner and Member of the Legislative Council [sound recording] / Interviewer, Diana Giese

archref.unittitle: Interview with Dr the Hon Bernice Pfitzner, medical practitioner and Member of the Legislative Council [sound recording] / Interviewer, Diana Giese
archref.abstract: 2 digital audio tapes (ca. 120 min.) + transcript (92 leaves) Pfitzner talks about growing up in Singapore and her family background, in particular her mother's determination to have a tertiary education and go into teaching. In 1949 her mother was the first woman to be elected to the Singapore City Council. She discusses the difficulties in having such a busy, famous mother. Pfitzner then talks about coming to Australia during WWII and her early schooling, returning to Singapore after the War, choosing medicine as a career, difficulties with her family over her choice of husband, doing post graduate work in child development at University of London, returning to Australia and her decision to go into Liberal politics.
